text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This revision includes the following changes:
a. Revised section title to Servicewide Policy Statement Process to reﬂect content. b. IRM

- Added information on the program scope and objectives, purpose, audience, roles, management controls and terms related to the IRM content. Updated content to reﬂect new functional office name, RAAS. Subsequent subsections renumbered. c. IRM

- Changed title to Purpose and Contents of Policy statements to reﬂect content. Changed “Service” Policies to “IRS” Policies based on Style guide. Merged content from previously contained in Designation of Policy Matters. Updated IRM
series to IRM
, as IRM
houses all Servicewide Policy Statements. Clariﬁed content. No procedural changes made. d. IRM

- Clariﬁed language on coordinating Policy Statements. Changed terminology “Headquarter Officials” to “Senior executives” based on current terminology of these officials. procedural changes made. e. IRM

- Added content to document the process for Revising and Issuing Policy Statements. Included Policy Statement publishing schedule and instructions for requesting a new Policy Statement and number. f. IRM
- Added new subsection on Procedures for Clearing Policy Statements to clarify steps for forwarding the Policy Statement for review and approval. g. IRM

- Added subsection on package requirements when sending to Office of Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic Resources (SPDER). Added table to display statement package content requirements, clariﬁed content, and merged SPDER review actions within this subsection. Added inclusion of a track change ﬁle for revisions and submission of paper and electronic version of the ﬁnal review package to SPDER. Added use of appropriate letterhead stationary for Commissioner/Deputy Commissioner signature. h. IRM
- Added new subsection on editorial changes of policy statements. i. Exhibit
- Updated the example for clarity and consistency with existing IRM
format. j. Exhibit
- Added an example of a revoked policy statement for clarity and understanding.
AUDIENCE
Table of Contents
Policy Statement Process
) Purpose: This IRM section deﬁnes the official Policy Statements of the Revenue Service and describes how to prepare, clear and issue them. and (
) Audience: These procedures apply to IRS employees who are responsible developing, creating, revising and revoking IRS Policy Statements for their Business Unit. (
) Policy Owner: The Office of Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic Resources (SPDER), is under Research, Applied Analytics and Statistics (RAAS). (
) Program Owner: SPDER is the program office responsible for overseeing Internal Management Document (IMD) process and providing guidance. (
) This IRM section enables the IRS to meet certain federal requirements to document, publish and maintain records of policies, authorities, procedures and organizational operations described in IRM
, Authority. (
) The IRS Restructuring and Reform Act of

resulted in a complete turing and reformatting of the IRM to align with IRS business processes. of the primary goals of IRS modernization was to restore and maintain the as the single, official compilation of IRS policies, procedures and (
) In

, IRS formed the Office of Servicewide Policy, Directives and Resources (formerly Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic SPDER is responsible for designing, implementing and monitoring a approach to managing and setting Servicewide policy for internal directives. See IRM
, Internal Management Document (IMD) Program and Responsibilities, for information about the affect of these changes. (
) By law, federal agencies are expected to document, publish and maintain records of policies, authorities, procedures and organizational operations. IRM is the source for the IRS. See IRM
, Authority for the and legal obligations of IMDs. (
) The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA),
USC

)(c), requires each agency to maintain and make available for public inspection and copying a current index providing identifying information for the public. The publication the Policy Statement on IRS.gov and in IRM
, Servicewide Policy ments fulﬁlls this legal responsibility. (
) The Director, Research Applied Analytics and Statistics (RAAS) is the executive responsible for the IMD program. (
) The Director, Strategic Business Solutions, is the program manager for SPDER. (
) Senior executives of each IRS organization are responsible for the IRS Policies (i.e. Policy Statements) for their respective programs. (
) The Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner review, approve and sign wide Policy Statements. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Servicewide Policy Statement Process
Purpose: This IRM section deﬁnes the official Policy Statements of the Internal Revenue Service and describes how to prepare, clear and issue them.
Policy Owner: The Office of Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic Resources (SPDER), is under Research, Applied Analytics and Statistics
Program Owner: SPDER is the program office responsible for overseeing the Internal Management Document (IMD) process and providing guidance.
Internal Management Documents (
) Senior executives of each IRS organization are responsible for reviewing, maintaining and archiving Policy Statements for their respective programs. Management (
) Beginning in FY

, SPDER will annually request the executives of each IRS organization to indicate the current status of their Policy Statement through the SPDER annual certiﬁcation. SPDER compiles the results into a report for Senior executives, managers, IMD coordinators, and staff which is used to support and improve IMD program management. (
) Policy Statement - An official IRS document conveying an important value to the IRS that governs and guides IRS personnel in the administration of the and Acronyms IRS. (
) Internal Management Documents (IMDs) -Official communications that designate policies, authorities and deliver instructions to IRS officials and employees. (
) Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) - A federal law (
USC

) that the right of the public to request access to federal agency records or tion including administrative procedural manuals and instructions to staff, unless the documents are exempt from disclosure. (

) Policy Statements publicize views concerning an important value of the IRS. These “IRS policies” govern and guide IRS personnel in the administration and Contents the IRS. The designation of any item as an ″IRS Policy″ concerns an issue Statements sufficient importance to warrant consideration, approval and signature by the Commissioner or Deputy Commissioners. (
) “IRS Policies” are issued as “Policy Statements” and are published in IRM

, Servicewide Policy Statements. They can form the basis for and instructions in the IRM. Policy statements are not, however, the ate vehicle to convey: • Instructions to staff • IRS interpretations of substantive tax provisions, or • Directions to the public. (

) Similarly, Policy Statements do not cover areas where basic decisions are claimed by another government agency or are settled by law. An exception may be made, for purposes of clarity and understanding, to combine and other policies if they are so interrelated that omitting those policies nating outside of the Service might cause an erroneous or misleading impression. Note: Any Policy Statement submitted for approval that contains procedural guidance will be returned to the originator for correction. (

) The only policies which can be issued as Policy Statements are those by the Commissioner or Deputy Commissioners, or those initiated and submitted for their approval by: • Senior executives, chiefs and directors directly reporting to the sioner and Deputy Commissioners • The Chief of Appeals • The National Taxpayer Advocate
Internal Management Documents System
Senior executives of each IRS organization are responsible for reviewing, maintaining and archiving Policy Statements for their respective programs.
Any Policy Statement submitted for approval that contains guidance will be returned to the originator for correction.

Statement Process
page (

) All Policy Statements must be coordinated with and reviewed by the Office Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic Resources (SPDER) PRIOR SIGNATURE of the Commissioner or Deputy Commissioners. (
) The Commissioner or one of the Deputy Commissioners approves and signs all Policy Statements on behalf of the IRS. (
) Policy Statements are numbered by the business processes to which they belong. For instance IRM
, Policy Statements for Organization, and Management Activities, contains all of the Policy Statements that relate IRS administrative activities. IRM
, Policy Statements for the Process, contains all of the Policy Statements that relate to the Examining Process. (
) Policies established by the Department of the Treasury or other offices of the executive branch, or by the legislative and judicial branches are not desig- nated as “IRS Policy Statements.” (

) Except where speciﬁcally stated, all references to the Commissioner and Deputy Commissioners are to the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, the Deputy Commissioner for Services and Enforcement and the Deputy sioner for Operations Support. (

) The words “servicewide policy” should not be used to designate an IRS position or procedure unless a Policy Statement on the matter has been or the IRS intends to establish one. Procedures established in conformance with approved Servicewide policies should be designated as procedures, in- structions, guidelines, positions, etc. (
) Policies issued from Divisions/Functions should not be called “Servicewide policies” and will not be published as such in the Policy Statement IRM

Deputy Commissioners, Chiefs, Division Commissioners or equivalent may elect to issue Division or Function policies which offer a Servicewide position on matters within their jurisdictions. For example, the Chief Human Capital Officer may elect to issue a functional policy on speciﬁc acceptable personnel practices, or the Chief Financial Officer may issue policies to the IRS toward good ﬁnancial management. The official may propose the as a Servicewide policy if it meets the standards set forth in paragraph (
) above or if, under other circumstances, the policy requires higher visibility. (

) Senior executives are responsible for Servicewide Policy Statements within their organization and clearing them through impacted offices, the Office of Chief Counsel and then the Office of SPDER, prior to submitting to the Com- missioner or Deputy Commissioners for approval and signature. Caution: SPDER will not process any Policy Statement packages without Chief Counsel review. Note: All Policy Statements must be cleared through the Office of SPDER

missioner or Deputy Commissioners for approval and signature.
(03-31-2020) Preparing and Coordinating Service Policy Statements
Note: All Policy Statements must be cleared through the Office of SPDER before forwarding to the Commissioner’s office for signature.

Senior executives are responsible for conducting a periodic review of the Policy Statements initiated by their organizations and then consulting the appropriate executives concerning proposals to revise or rescind Policy Statements when necessary.

) Policy Statements are numbered based on business processes to support modernization of the IRS. For example, IRS Policy relating to the examining process was renumbered P-
-XX; IRS Policy relating to human capital agement was renumbered P-

-XX, etc. Although Policy Statements are numbered to correspond to the processes represented by the IRM part numbers, the policies apply to any and all IRS personnel and activities according to their terms. For a complete listing of IRM part numbers see

Document Contents d. Form 13839, Note to Reviewer Contains a clear and concise explanation of the change being made or, if new, why the Policy Statement is being issued. It should identify any major issues, and the signiﬁ- cance of any change or reason for cancellation. Note: Any package submitted for approval/signature without a Note to Reviewer will be returned to the initiator as this is a require- ment of the Commissioner’s Office and SPDER. e. Servicewide Policy Statement Process
d. Staff Assistant, if Commissioner approves; e. Commissioner (
) SPDER will forward the package and Form
to approving official’s (

) After signed policy statement has been returned to SPDER, within seven calendar days SPDER will: a. Include the “approval date” as the revision or issue date in the posted to IRS.gov and SPDER website; b. Notify the submitter and IMD Coordinator of the signature and c. Request Online Services to post the new/revised Policy Statement to FOIA Library on IRS.gov; d. Scan the signed Policy Statement; and e. Forward the ﬁnal package to the IRS Historical Research Library. (
) SPDER will incorporate the new/revised Policy Statement into IRM
on the semi-annual schedule (January/July). (
) In very limited situations, authors may request modiﬁcations to a published Policy Statement for editorial changes that do not change the meaning of content. (
) Editorial changes are limited to: • Updating organizational terms and titles to current terms or titles • Correcting typographical errors, e.g., spelling or grammatical errors (
) For editorial change considerations, forward the following to *SPDER: a. Track changes Word ﬁle of the Policy Statement b. Final Word ﬁle with no tracked changes c. Completed Form
, Note to Reviewer indicating the reason for change d. Form
signed by the organization’s Executive approving the (
) After review and agreement, SPDER will update the Policy Statement in
based on the semi-annual schedule (January/July) and notate the editorial correction in the Manual Transmittal. (
) The published Policy Statement effective date and revision number will the same. (
) SPDER will retain the ﬁles and forward to the IRS Historical Research for record retention and documentation.
(03-31-2020) Editorial Changes for Policy Statements
Updating organizational terms and titles to current terms or titles Correcting typographical errors, e.g., spelling or grammatical errors
1.11 Internal Management Documents System
This Page Intentionally Left Blank
Policy Statement 1-27, Protection from Reprisal for Whistleblowing
Effective Date: (leave blank; date will be inserted once approved)
Protection from Reprisal for Whistleblowing

(2) The Internal Revenue Service recognizes and endorses the rights of employees to raise issues and to ﬁle complaints, subject to applicable law and regulations. The Service is committed to a work environment that is free from retaliation and reprisal, including reprisal for whistleblowing.
(3) The Service will foster a climate for employees where issues can be discussed openly and where of misconduct and impropriety are immediately reported and appropriately acted on.

(4) Managers and supervisors are responsible for ensuring that the personnel actions they take conform to civil service laws and regulations. Those laws and regulations include retaliation for whistleblowing on the list of pro- hibited personnel practices. Managers and supervisors will take vigorous corrective action when a prohibited personnel practice occurs.
Exhibit 1.11.3-2 (03-31-2020) Sample Rescinded Policy Statement
Policy Statement 1-44 (Rescinded), Monitoring of Employee Telephone Conversations
Rescinded: (leave blank; date will be inserted once approved)
(1) Monitoring of Employee Telephone Conversations

(2) This policy statement is rescinded. Since approximately 2004, the Service has been using a telephone software system for recording interactions between IRS customer service personnel and taxpayers or their rep- resentatives. The recordings are then made available through a browser-based interface to managers and quality reviewers, enabling remote assessment of employee performance and customer service quality. The of the telephone software system was negotiated between the Service and the National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU) for all appropriate areas of implementation.
(3) Signed: Steven T. Miller, Deputy Commissioner for Services and Enforcement
